awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Proof in Secondary Classrooms: Decomposing a Central Mathematical Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, funded as part of the CAREER program, would add to the knowledge base on the teaching and learning of proof in the context of the most prevalent course/topic in which proof is taught in the K-12 curriculum, geometry. Given the centrality of the role of proof, and the persistent difficulties in teaching proof in the K-12 and undergraduate curriculum, the topic is of vital importance. The work is novel, focusing on an area of proof that is understudied, the introduction of students to the topic of proof. While building on prior work in proof, the project will tackle an important area of beginning to teach proof, which may lead to broader innovations at both the K-12 and undergraduate level. The project will produce a resource, a set of lessons, which can be used widely and are likely to be broadly disseminated based on the PI's previous NSF-supported work, which has been broadly disseminated to practitioner audiences. 

The goal of the project is to develop an intervention to support the teaching and learning of proof in the context of geometry. This study takes as its premise that if we introduce proof, by first teaching students particular sub-goals of proof, such as how to draw a conclusion from a given statement and a definition, then students will be more successful with constructing proofs on their own. The 5-year design and development study builds on the researcher's prior work from a Knowles Science Teaching Fellowship (KSTF) grant to study how teachers introduce proof to students. This study will build on the prior work to refine a framework for introducing proof developed in the KSTF study. Using this framework the researcher will work with five high school geometry teachers to develop lessons via Lesson Study methods to introduce sub-goals of proof. The PI will study the impact of the use of these lessons on students' ability to perform proofs, and compare to students of ten teachers who will not have participated in the intervention.

por.por_cntn:
In an effort to bolster the success of secondary mathematics students, the Proof in Secondary Classrooms (PISC) team developed and piloted a research-based intervention to support the teaching and learning of proof in high school geometry - a focal area of secondary school mathematics that has been identified as a long-standing challenge for both teachers and students.

A primary research objective of the PISC Project was to develop and study the use of a pedagogical framework and a corresponding set of lessons to support teachers to improve students’ success with proof. More specifically, the Geometry Proof Scaffold (GPS) served as the guiding framework for the development of a comprehensive set of 16 focal lessons. These lessons encompassed student materials, detailed lesson plans, and other supporting resources and were continuously improved throughout the project.

The primary educational objective of this project was to support mathematics educators in understanding particular sub-goals of proof and developing strategies for teaching them. To achieve this goal, the core project teachers participated in sustained professional development for three years. Additionally, the PISC lessons were integrated into the University of Delaware’s Geometry and Measurement for Middle School Teachers course, fostering the preparation of future teachers. Thus, the findings from the PISC Project have implications for teaching proof in secondary classrooms and at the undergraduate level; efforts to disseminate results to both audiences are ongoing.

The project resulted in numerous noteworthy outcomes. First, the GPS garnered positive feedback from the classroom teachers who interacted with it in terms of both its face validity and utility as a guiding framework for teaching proof. The GPS, which is organized by sub-goals such as Defining and Working with Diagrams, is then further sub-divided into manageable competencies for each sub-goal. The underlying idea is that proof can be decomposed and then recomposed (Janssen, Grossman, & Westbroek, 2015) so that the complex task of teaching proof can be approached by teaching and providing targeted student feedback on particular components of the proving process, such as Drawing Conclusions from “Given” information or theorem hypotheses.  

Second, the PISC Project’s inquiry revealed significant ways that the PISC curriculum supported students’ acquisition of knowledge about proving in geometry. For example, after pre-tests and post-tests were administered to 1550 and 1278 students, respectively, during three years of the study, psychometric analyses of both assessments and further rigorous statistical analyses of comparative outcomes were carried out. Through these analyses, gains made by students who received the treatment (i.e., PISC lessons) were revealed to be significantly larger than for those students who learned proof in geometry from commercially available curriculum programs.  

Third, the PISC classroom observations and inquiry into student thinking uncovered important misconceptions and revealed critical competencies present in the thinking and behaviors of students. Common misconceptions, such as confusion about different kinds of bisectors (e.g., line segment and perpendicular bisectors) and the belief that one can draw valid conclusions from diagrams were explored, and strategies for overcoming confusion were identified. Also, through individual student interviews conducted with Smartpens, students who were successful with a proof problem set were observed exhibiting specific competencies while working on the proofs, such as productively attending to the “Given” information and using the provided diagram as a resource for the proof. By contrast, students who struggled to correctly complete the proofs exhibited these competencies far less often or not at all.

Finally, an exemplary classroom teacher’s instructional routine for proving theorems was documented, providing a valuable resource for a range of mathematics instructors. The documentation of this instructional routine can inform both secondary classroom teachers’ work as well as elevate mathematicians’ and other university mathematics instructors’ proof-teaching strategies.

Although we continue to analyze data to investigate the ways and extent to which this approach to teaching proof might improve mathematics classroom outcomes, our team’s work in developing and refining a pedagogical framework and materials that emphasize a new approach to teaching proof is an important step in making progress on this persistent curricular challenge. The PISC Project’s fresh perspective paves the way to advance the field in better preparing secondary mathematics teachers and consequently improving student learning outcomes with proving - a process that is considered fundamental to doing mathematics. 

More information about this project can be found on the PISC website.

 

Reference

Janssen, F., Grossman, P., & Westbroek, H. (2015). Facilitating decomposition and recomposition in practice-based teacher education: The power of modularity. Teaching and Teacher Education, 51, 137-146.
